posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked: Now that the season is over, I want to see the most overpowered, improperly spec’d, and absurd uses of a CIM -class motor that you encountered during Reefscape.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: What qualifies as a CIM class motor?

posts.name: Erik Boyle
posts.cooked:
Any motor with the CIM mounting pattern, #10-32 holes on a 2" bolt circle. That includes (by rough order of release date iirc):

CIM

Mini CIM

NEO

Falcon 500

Kraken X60

NEO Vortex

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Somewhere between Thunderstruck and Country Roads

posts.custom_user_title: Somewhere between Thunderstruck and Country Roads

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: A team I know used redline motors for their elevator while using a kraken for their coral intake.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
Funny that we just made a post about this mechanism. A NEO Vortex spinning a lead screw ~1.5 rotations to engage a friction brake.

FRC 6995: NOMAD 2025 CAD Release CAD

I will defend this as a solid design decision based on the utility of the spinning shell and sacrificial shaft for the coupler, but I doubt we needed the power.

posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked: kinda the reverse of this, but there was a team at UTWV with a 2-Redline elevator. In fact all of their motors besides their drivetrain (standard mk4 IIRC) were redlines.

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
Paul_R:

In fact all of their motors besides their drivetrain (standard mk4 IIRC) were redlines.

Playing on hard-mode I see.

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked:
CuteRedpandas:

A team I know used redline motors for their elevator

Paul_R:

there was a team at UTWV with a 2-Redline elevator

What in the 2018??? I swear, I just “4x 775 elevator” on the 254 2018 tech binder…

posts.name: tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826
posts.cooked:
Well it was not for Reefscape, but back in 2018 one of our students made what could be the most ridiculous CIM based mechanism of all time.  We needed a brake to keep our elevator from drifting down when the power was turned off.  So he made an air brake by cutting the wires off a CIM , cutting a hole in the case and putting a small pancake pneumatic cylinder on it to lock the spindle in place.  IIRC the crazy thing used a 2 CIM gear box where one drove the elevator up and the other toggled on with the brake when power to the drive motor stopped.  We had every inspector at Lake Superior looking it over…and I think some from Northern Lights too!

So many yellow hats trying to figure this thing out!
